content: More than 53,000 commercial vessels travel the world's waters, regulated by international protocols and U.S. laws to prevent pollution and protect marine resources. However, there are gaps in regulations, enforcement, and concerns about environmental impacts. The maritime industry, including the cruise industry, faces gaps in regulations, enforcement, and environmental concerns. Cruise ships make up about 13% of the world shipping fleet and are a significant contributor to the U.S. economy, providing $40 billion in benefits in 2009. The cruise industry is a growing contributor to the U.S. economy, providing $40 billion in benefits in 2009 and creating over 357,000 U.S. jobs. The number of cruise passengers worldwide has been increasing at an average annual growth rate of 7.4% since 1990, with an estimated 14.3 million passengers in 2010. The worldwide cruise ship fleet consists of over 230 ships, with the majority being foreign-flagged, particularly from Liberia and Panama. Foreign-flag cruise vessels owned by six companies make up nearly 95% of passenger ships operating in U.S. waters. The cruise industry is growing, with Liberia and Panama being popular flag countries. Foreign-flag cruise vessels owned by six companies make up 95% of ships in U.S. waters. Ships are getting bigger and more luxurious, with an average size increase of 90 feet every five years. The industry aims to show that cruising is safe for passengers and tourist communities. Cruise ships, often compared to "floating cities," generate large amounts of waste during voyages. A typical one-week trip with 3,000 passengers and crew produces 210,000 gallons of sewage, 1 million gallons of graywater, 130 gallons of hazardous wastes, 8 tons of solid waste, and 25,000 gallons of other waste. The industry is focused on demonstrating the safety and health of cruising for passengers and visited communities. Environmental advocates have raised concerns about the risks posed by the large amounts of waste generated by cruise ships, including sewage, graywater, hazardous wastes, solid waste, and oily bilge water. Enforcement of existing laws for managing these wastes is considered weak, with a 2000 GAO report highlighting numerous cases of illegal discharges by foreign-flag cruise ships between 1993 and 1998. Between 1993 and 1998, foreign-flag cruise ships were involved in 87 confirmed illegal discharge cases in U.S. waters, with 83% of cases involving oil or oil-based products. 72% of the illegal discharges were accidental, 15% intentional, and 13% undetermined. The GAO found that 72% of illegal discharges from foreign-flag ships in U.S. waters were accidental, 15% intentional, and 13% undetermined. Cruise ships accounted for 4% of these cases, with some leading to criminal prosecutions and hefty fines.
